eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Turret
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A turret movement with customizable speed, acceleration and stop angles.
description: With this behavior, you can make an object rotate like a turret toward a position.
It may be used with the **Bullet** extension to fire objects.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: LinkTools
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Conditions to use Linked Objects as a graph and a path finding movement behavior
description: This provides:
* "Can reach through links" conditions, useful to check if an object is linked to another through one or more other linked objects.
* a path finding movement behavior that uses objects links (instead of obstacles for the other behavior)
For instance, it can be helpful for grid-based games like:
* Match-3 (see BimBam example)
* Tactical (see Tactical example)
* City builders (see City Builder example)
* Point and click (bypass obstacles with a predetermined polygonal chain)

eventsFunctions.description: Link to neighbors on a rectangular grid
eventsFunctions.fullName: Link to neighbors on a rectangular grid
eventsFunctions.name: LinkRectangularNeighbors
eventsFunctions.sentence: Link _PARAM1_ and its neighbors _PARAM2_  on a rectangular grid with cell dimensions: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_

parameters.longDescription: The 2 objects can't be the same.
parameters.name: Neighbor

eventsFunctions.fullName: Link to neighbors on a hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: LinkHexagonalNeighbors

parameters.longDescription: The 2 objects can't be the same.
parameters.name: Neighbor

eventsFunctions.description: Link to neighbors on an isometric grid
eventsFunctions.fullName: Link to neighbors on an isometric grid
eventsFunctions.name: LinkIsometricRectangularNeighbors
eventsFunctions.sentence: Link _PARAM1_ and its neighbors _PARAM2_  on an isometric grid with cell dimensions: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_

parameters.longDescription: The 2 objects can't be the same.
parameters.name: Neighbor

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Bounce the object off another object it just touched.
description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched.
> ⚠️ This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
The Breakout-like example uses this extension to make balls bounce ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://breakout)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movement.

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be calculated *to go toward the specified angle (the "normal angle")*. For example, if the object is arriving at this exact angle, it will bounce in the opposite direction.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Bounce off another object toward a specified angle
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffSpecificAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Bounce _PARAM0_ off _PARAM2_ assuming a normal angle of _PARAM3_

events.comment:
Check if there is a collision between the object and an obstacle and if so, do the bounce by stopping the object and adding a force so that it goes in the "reflected" direction, using the "normal" angle provided. 
This provides a realistic bounce.

parameters.description: The "normal" angle, in degrees, to bounce against
parameters.longDescription: This can be understood at the direction that the bounce must go toward.
parameters.name: NormalAngle

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be vertical, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly horizontal obstacle* (like the top/bottom of the screen in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 90 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: -90 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffVertically

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be horizontal, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly vertical obstacle* (like paddles in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 0 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: 180 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffHorizontally

eventsFunctions.description: the number of times this object has bounced off another object.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceCount

propertyDescriptors.label: Bounce count
propertyDescriptors.description: Number of times this object has bounced off another object
propertyDescriptors.name: BounceCount

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: HexagonalGrid
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Snap objects to an hexagonal grid.
description: It allows to snap objects on an hexagonal grid.
It's useful for:
- level editors
- building systems ([open the city builder example online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://city-builder))
A [simple example](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://snap-object-to-grid) shows how to snap objects that are dragged with the mouse.

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToPointyToppedHexagonalGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual pointy topped hexagonal grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

inlineCode: // Find the hexagon cube coordinates for a given position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// Hexagon cube coordinates to hexagon position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// const positionX = Math.sqrt(3) * roundX  + Math.sqrt(3)/2 * roundZ;

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual row height will be 3/4 of this.
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd rows are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 3/4" offset to make it the other way.
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToFlatToppedHexagonalGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual flat topped hexagonal grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

events.comment: Note: this is the exact same code as for pointy topped hexagonal grid with x and y swapped.

inlineCode: // Find the hexagon cube coordinates for a given position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// Hexagon cube coordinates to hexagon position
// The following is a simplified version of this:
// const positionX = Math.sqrt(3) * roundX  + Math.sqrt(3)/2 * roundZ;

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual column width will be 3/4 of this.
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd columns are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 3/4" offset to make it the other way.
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctions.description: Snap object to a virtual bubble grid (this is not the grid used in the editor).
eventsFunctions.fullName: Snap objects to a virtual bubble grid
eventsFunctions.name: SnapObjectToBubbleGrid
eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM1_ to a virtual bubble grid using cells with width: _PARAM2_px, height _PARAM3_px and an offset position (_PARAM4_; _PARAM5_)

events.comment:
This grid is like bottles stacking, odd lines are shifted from half a cell. 

On an hexagonal grid a line height is 3/4 of sprite height but with bubbles it is sin(60°) that is around 0.866 which is near 7/8 = 0.875
(7/6)/(3/4) = 7/6
Using this ratio, the cellHeigt gives the 7/8 line height and this allows integer position as assets are often a multiple of 8.

parameters.description: Objects to snap to the virtual grid
parameters.name: Object

parameters.description: Width of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: CellWidth

parameters.description: Height of a cell of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: The actual row height will be 7/8 of this.
parameters.name: CellHeight

parameters.description: Offset on the X axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.name: OffsetX

parameters.description: Offset on the Y axis of the virtual grid (in pixels)
parameters.longDescription: Odd rows are shifted from half a cell, use a "CellHeight * 7/8" offset to make it the other way
parameters.name: OffsetY

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.description: Reset the state of the button.
eventsFunctions.name: ResetState

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is not used.
eventsFunctions.name: IsIdle

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button was just clicked.
eventsFunctions.name: IsClicked

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the cursor is hovered over the button.
eventsFunctions.name: IsHovered

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is either hovered or pressed but not hovered.
eventsFunctions.name: IsFocused

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressed

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed outside with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressedOutside

eventsFunctions.description: the touch id that is using the button or 0 if none.
eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsBasedObjects.description: A button that can be customized.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelSpriteButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.
